data.title: Donna Summer, Grammy-Winning Disco Legend, Dies at 63
data.meta_description: Donna Summer, the five-time Grammy Award–winning singer and songwriter known as “The Queen of Disco,” died this morning at the age of 63 after a battle with breast cancer. Born in Boston, Summer served as a back-up singer for Three Dog Night before achieving solo fame with her first hit, “Love to Love You Baby.” Over the course of back-to-back multi-platinum albums and popular singles that included “Last Dance,“ “Bad Girls,” and “She Works Hard for the Money,” she helped define the sound of the late 70s and early 80s. Summer, who was the first artist to win a Grammy for best dance recording (for “Carry On” in 1997), was inducted into the Dance Music Hall of Fame in New York City in 2004.
data.text:
Donna Summer, the five-time Grammy Award–winning singer and songwriter known as “The Queen of Disco,” died this morning at the age of 63 after a battle with breast cancer. Born in Boston, Summer served as a back-up singer for Three Dog Night before achieving solo fame with her first hit, “Love to Love You Baby.” Over the course of back-to-back multi-platinum albums and popular singles that included “Last Dance,“ “Bad Girls,” and “She Works Hard for the Money,” she helped define the sound of the late 70s and early 80s. Summer, who was the first artist to win a Grammy for best dance recording (for “Carry On” in 1997), was inducted into the Dance Music Hall of Fame in New York City in 2004.

Summer is survived by her husband, singer and producer Bruce Sudano, their daughters, Brooklyn and Amanda, and Summer’s daughter, Mimi, from a previous marriage. Summer’s family confirmed her death in a press release, adding that they are “at peace celebrating her extraordinary life and her continue legacy.”

Read Donna Summer’s and others’ recollections of the disco era in V.F.’s oral history, “Boogie Nights.”
